External Resource Links.Resource Title: Jim Crow and Plessy v. Ferguson

Text: Supreme Court validates separate-but-equal principle in _Plessy v. Ferguson_
Name: 1896: Supreme Court validates separate-but-equal principle in Plessy v. Ferguson

External Resource Links.Resource Title: Niagara Movement - Cornerstone of the Modern Civil Rights Movement

Text: Niagara Movement, forerunner of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP), formed for school integration, voting rights, and assisting black political candidates
Name: 1905: Niagara Movement, forerunner of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP), formed for school integration, voting rights, and assisting black political candidates

Text: A race riot organized by the white supremacist Redshirts in Wilmington, NC which led to the massacre of an estimated 14-60 blacks, the burning of the black newspaper "The Daily Record," the banishment of the legitimately elected biracial Fusion Party government, and the implementation of Jim Crow in North Carolina.
Name: 1898: A race riot organized by the white supremacist Redshirts in Wilmington, NC which led to the massacre of an estimated 14-60 blacks, the burning of the black newspaper "The Daily Record," the banishment of the legitimately elected biracial Fusion Party government, and the implementation of Jim Crow in North Carolina.

Text: Greensburg, Indiana, race riot in reaction to black migration north.
Name: 1906: Greensburg, Indiana, race riot in reaction to black migration north.

Text: National Association for the Advancement of Colored People formed.
Name: 1909: National Association for the Advancement of Colored People formed.

Text: Movie _Birth of a Nation_ released; though a smash hit, its blatant racism provokes opposition from the newly formed NAACP and other black organizations.  This romanticization of the Ku Klux Klan led to its revival at Stone Mountain, GA.
Name: 1915: Movie Birth of a Nation released; though a smash hit, its blatant racism provokes opposition from the newly formed NAACP and other black organizations.  This romanticization of the Ku Klux Klan led to its revival at Stone Mountain, GA.

Text: Congress of Racial Equality (CORE) founded.
Name: 1942: Congress of Racial Equality (CORE) founded.

Text: Executive Order 9981 issued by President Harry Truman desegregated the US military.
Name: 1948: Executive Order 9981 issued by President Harry Truman desegregated the US military.

External Resource Links.Resource Title: Brown v. Board of Education in PBS' The Supreme Court

Text: _Brown v. Board_ Supreme Court decision overturns separate-but-equal principle.  This landmark case established racially segregated schools as unconstitutional.
Name: 1954: Brown v. Board Supreme Court decision overturns separate-but-equal principle.  This landmark case established racially segregated schools as unconstitutional.

Text: Montgomery Bus Boycott brings Martin Luther King, Jr., to prominence.  The campaign lasted from December 5, 1955, the Monday after Rosa Parks was arrested for refusing to give up her seat to a white person, to December 20, 1956 when Browder v. Gayle went into effect.  Browder v. Gayle declared that bus segregation was unconstitutional.
Name: 1955: Montgomery Bus Boycott brings Martin Luther King, Jr., to prominence.  The campaign lasted from December 5, 1955, the Monday after Rosa Parks was arrested for refusing to give up her seat to a white person, to December 20, 1956 when Browder v. Gayle went into effect.  Browder v. Gayle declared that bus segregation was unconstitutional.

Text: 14-year-old Emmett Till murdered in Mississippi for whistling at a white woman.
Name: 1955: 14-year-old Emmett Till murdered in Mississippi for whistling at a white woman.

Text: The Little Rock Nine were a group of African-American high school students enrolled in Little Rock Central High School.  The decision to integrate the school was opposed by Arkansas Governor Orval Faubus who deployed the National Guard to prevent the Little Rock Nine from attending the segregated school.  President Eisenhower issued Executive Order 10730 which ordered U.S. Army troops and federalized the Arkansas National Guard to enforce school desegregation in Little Rock, Arkansas.
Name: 1957: The Little Rock Nine were a group of African-American high school students enrolled in Little Rock Central High School.  The decision to integrate the school was opposed by Arkansas Governor Orval Faubus who deployed the National Guard to prevent the Little Rock Nine from attending the segregated school.  President Eisenhower issued Executive Order 10730 which ordered U.S. Army troops and federalized the Arkansas National Guard to enforce school desegregation in Little Rock, Arkansas.

Text: Southern Christian Leadership Conference (SCLC) founded with Martin Luther King, Jr. as president. The concepts of nonviolent mass action, affiliation with local community organization, and being a movement open to all were cornerstones of the group's strategy.
Name: 1957: Southern Christian Leadership Conference (SCLC) founded with Martin Luther King, Jr. as president. The concepts of nonviolent mass action, affiliation with local community organization, and being a movement open to all were cornerstones of the group's strategy.

Text: The Greensboro Four, students at North Carolina A&T State University conducted a sit-in at the "whites only" Woolworth lunch counter in Greensboro, North Carolina.  Their actions inspired a sit-in movement across the United States to desegregate Woolworth.
Name: 1960: The Greensboro Four, students at North Carolina A&T State University conducted a sit-in at the "whites only" Woolworth lunch counter in Greensboro, North Carolina.  Their actions inspired a sit-in movement across the United States to desegregate Woolworth.

Text: Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee (SNCC) founded at Shaw University, Raleigh, North Carolina.
Name: 1960: Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee (SNCC) founded at Shaw University, Raleigh, North Carolina.

Text: CORE and SNCC sends integrated Freedom Rider groups to protest segregation on southern buses which was declared unconstitutional under the Supreme Court ruling in _Morgan v. Virginia_ and _Boynton v. Virginia._ Southern local and state police viewed the Freedom Riders as criminals and arrested them in some locations.  The police in Birmingham, Alabama collaborated with the KKK and allowed white mobs to attack Freedom Riders and burn the bus.
Name: 1961: CORE and SNCC sends integrated Freedom Rider groups to protest segregation on southern buses which was declared unconstitutional under the Supreme Court ruling in Morgan v. Virginia and Boynton v. Virginia. Southern local and state police viewed the Freedom Riders as criminals and arrested them in some locations.  The police in Birmingham, Alabama collaborated with the KKK and allowed white mobs to attack Freedom Riders and burn the bus.

Text: U.S. troops deployed to Oxford, Mississippi, after rioting follows James Meredith's matriculation at University of Mississippi law school.
Name: 1962: U.S. troops deployed to Oxford, Mississippi, after rioting follows James Meredith's matriculation at University of Mississippi law school.

Text: The Birmingham Movement was organized by SCLC to bring attention integration efforts in Birmingham, Alabama.  Nonviolent civil rights protesters were met with police dogs and fire hoses.  These nonviolent protests brought the fight for integration into the national spotlight.
Name: 1963: The Birmingham Movement was organized by SCLC to bring attention integration efforts in Birmingham, Alabama.  Nonviolent civil rights protesters were met with police dogs and fire hoses.  These nonviolent protests brought the fight for integration into the national spotlight.

Text: NAACP Mississippi field secretary Medgar Evers murdered in Jackson, Mississippi.
Name: 1963: NAACP Mississippi field secretary Medgar Evers murdered in Jackson, Mississippi.

External Resource Links.Resource Title: March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom

Text: Around 250,000 people gathered in Washington, D.C. to march to advocate for civil and economic right for African-Americans.  During the march, Martin Luther King, Jr. delivered his "I Have a Dream" speech in front of the Lincoln Memorial.
Name: 1963: Around 250,000 people gathered in Washington, D.C. to march to advocate for civil and economic right for African-Americans.  During the march, Martin Luther King, Jr. delivered his "I Have a Dream" speech in front of the Lincoln Memorial.

Text: Four girls were killed by a bomb planted by the Ku Klux Klan at the 16th Street Baptist Church in Birmingham, Alabama.
Name: 1963: Four girls were killed by a bomb planted by the Ku Klux Klan at the 16th Street Baptist Church in Birmingham, Alabama.

Text: 24th Amendment outlaws poll taxes for national elections.
Name: 1964: 24th Amendment outlaws poll taxes for national elections.

Text: The Mississippi Summer Project also known as Freedom Summer organized a voter registration drive to register African-Americans in Mississippi to vote.
Name: 1964: The Mississippi Summer Project also known as Freedom Summer organized a voter registration drive to register African-Americans in Mississippi to vote.

External Resource Links.Resource Title: Murders of Chaney, Goodman, and Schwerner

Text: Freedom Summer volunteers James Chaney, Andrew Goodman, and Michael Schwerner were murdered by members of the Ku Klux Klan in Neshoba County, Mississippi.
Name: 1964: Freedom Summer volunteers James Chaney, Andrew Goodman, and Michael Schwerner were murdered by members of the Ku Klux Klan in Neshoba County, Mississippi.

Text: The Civil Rights Act of 1964 outlaws discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, or national origin by employers and in public accommodations.
Name: 1964: The Civil Rights Act of 1964 outlaws discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, or national origin by employers and in public accommodations.

Text: The Organization of Afro-American Unity was created by Malcolm X to fight for the human rights of African-Americans and promote cooperation between Africans and people of African descent in the Americas.
Name: 1964: The Organization of Afro-American Unity was created by Malcolm X to fight for the human rights of African-Americans and promote cooperation between Africans and people of African descent in the Americas.

Text: The Selma to Montgomery March was organized as a nonviolent protest by African-Americans who wanted to exercise the right to vote by marching 54 miles from Selma, Alabama to the state capital Montgomery.  The first march, known as "Bloody Sunday," was violently repressed by Alabama State Troopers and Dallas County Police Officers.  Ten days later, the protesters successfully began their march from Selma to Montgomery.
Name: 1965: The Selma to Montgomery March was organized as a nonviolent protest by African-Americans who wanted to exercise the right to vote by marching 54 miles from Selma, Alabama to the state capital Montgomery.  The first march, known as "Bloody Sunday," was violently repressed by Alabama State Troopers and Dallas County Police Officers.  Ten days later, the protesters successfully began their march from Selma to Montgomery.

Text: Voting Rights Act abolishes literacy tests and other practices to obstruct minority voting.
Name: 1965: Voting Rights Act abolishes literacy tests and other practices to obstruct minority voting.

Text: Malcolm X is assassinated in New York City.
Name: 1965: Malcolm X is assassinated in New York City.

Text: The Watts Riots broke out in Los Angeles, California due to tensions between the police and African-Americans living in the highly impoverished Watts neighborhood.  The riot was a result of longstanding issues including high unemployment, substandard housing, and inadequate schooling for the citizens of Watts.
Name: 1965: The Watts Riots broke out in Los Angeles, California due to tensions between the police and African-Americans living in the highly impoverished Watts neighborhood.  The riot was a result of longstanding issues including high unemployment, substandard housing, and inadequate schooling for the citizens of Watts.

Text: Executive Order 11246 establishes requirements for non-discriminatory practices in hiring and employment on the part of U.S. government contractors.
Name: 1965: Executive Order 11246 establishes requirements for non-discriminatory practices in hiring and employment on the part of U.S. government contractors.

Text: SNCC leader Stokely Carmichael coins the phrase "Black Power."  Carmichael saw the concept of "Black Power" as a means of solidarity between individuals within the movement.
Name: 1966: SNCC leader Stokely Carmichael coins the phrase "Black Power."  Carmichael saw the concept of "Black Power" as a means of solidarity between individuals within the movement.

Text: Black Panthers founded in Oakland, California by Bobby Seale and Huey Newton.
Name: 1966: Black Panthers founded in Oakland, California by Bobby Seale and Huey Newton.

Text: Supreme Court case _Loving v. Virginia_ rules that laws banning interracial marriage violate the Fourteenth Amendment.
Name: 1967: Supreme Court case Loving v. Virginia rules that laws banning interracial marriage violate the Fourteenth Amendment.

Text: The Long, Hot Summer was a series of race riots that erupted across the United States, stemming from racial inequality, poverty, and unemployment.  The largest and most deadly riots occurred in Detroit, Michigan and Newark, New Jersey.
Name: 1967: The Long, Hot Summer was a series of race riots that erupted across the United States, stemming from racial inequality, poverty, and unemployment.  The largest and most deadly riots occurred in Detroit, Michigan and Newark, New Jersey.

External Resource Links.Resource Title: Assassination of Martin Luther King, Jr.

Text: Reverend Martin Luther King, Jr. assassinated in Memphis, Tennessee.  Riots erupt in cities across the United States.
Name: 1968: Reverend Martin Luther King, Jr. assassinated in Memphis, Tennessee.  Riots erupt in cities across the United States.

Text: Civil Rights Act of 1968 outlaws discrimination in the sale or rental of housing.
Name: 1968: Civil Rights Act of 1968 outlaws discrimination in the sale or rental of housing.

Text: Voting Rights Act of 1965 renewed.
Name: 1970: Voting Rights Act of 1965 renewed.

External Resource Links.Resource Title: Swann v. Charlotte-Mecklenburg Board of Education

Text: Supreme Court upholds busing for integration in _Swann v. Charlotte-Mecklenburg Board_.
Name: 1971: Supreme Court upholds busing for integration in Swann v. Charlotte-Mecklenburg Board.

External Resource Links.Resource Title: Regents of the Univ. of Cal. v. Bakke

Text: _Regents of the University of California v. Bakke_ bars racial quotas for college admissions but affirms the constitutionality of affirmative action programs.
Name: 1978: Regents of the University of California v. Bakke bars racial quotas for college admissions but affirms the constitutionality of affirmative action programs.

Text: Ronald Reagan established Martin Luther King Jr. Day (MLK Day) as a federal holiday to be observed on the third Monday of January.  The holiday was first observed on January 20, 1986.
Name: 1983: Ronald Reagan established Martin Luther King Jr. Day (MLK Day) as a federal holiday to be observed on the third Monday of January.  The holiday was first observed on January 20, 1986.

Text: The Million Man March was organized by Louis Farrakhan of Nation of Islam and Dr. Benjamin Chavis of the NAACP.  With a crowd estimated between 400,000 and 1,100,000 people, it was the largest gathering of African-Americans in American history.
Name: 1995: The Million Man March was organized by Louis Farrakhan of Nation of Islam and Dr. Benjamin Chavis of the NAACP.  With a crowd estimated between 400,000 and 1,100,000 people, it was the largest gathering of African-Americans in American history.

Text: James Byrd Jr. is murdered by white supremacists in Jasper, Texas.  The murder evoked imagery lynchings.  His killers were the first white men sentenced to death for killing a black person in the history of Texas.
Name: 1998: James Byrd Jr. is murdered by white supremacists in Jasper, Texas.  The murder evoked imagery lynchings.  His killers were the first white men sentenced to death for killing a black person in the history of Texas.

Text: Senator Barack Obama of Illinois is elected the 44th President of the United States, the first African-American to hold the office.
Name: 2008: Senator Barack Obama of Illinois is elected the 44th President of the United States, the first African-American to hold the office.

Text: Trayvon Martin is killed by George Zimmerman, a neighborhood watch coordinator in Sanford, Florida.  Zimmerman claimed he shot Martin in self-defense.  Zimmerman was acquitted of second-degree murder and manslaughter under the "Stand Your Ground" law in Florida.
Name: 2012: Trayvon Martin is killed by George Zimmerman, a neighborhood watch coordinator in Sanford, Florida.  Zimmerman claimed he shot Martin in self-defense.  Zimmerman was acquitted of second-degree murder and manslaughter under the "Stand Your Ground" law in Florida.

Text: The Black Live Matter movement is created after the acquittal of George Zimmerman.  Born out of an online hashtag (#BlackLivesMatter), the Black Lives Matter movement advocates against police violence towards black people and to eradicate white supremacy.
Name: 2013: The Black Live Matter movement is created after the acquittal of George Zimmerman.  Born out of an online hashtag (#BlackLivesMatter), the Black Lives Matter movement advocates against police violence towards black people and to eradicate white supremacy.

Text: Riots break in Los Angeles after four Los Angeles Police officers were acquitted for excessive violence and beating of Rodney King during his arrest.  King's arrested had been videotaped and widely televised.  The riots last 6 days and 63 people were killed.
Name: 1992: Riots break in Los Angeles after four Los Angeles Police officers were acquitted for excessive violence and beating of Rodney King during his arrest.  King's arrested had been videotaped and widely televised.  The riots last 6 days and 63 people were killed.

Text: Michael Brown is fatally shot by white police officer Darren Wilson in Ferguson, Missouri.  The incident led to unrest in Ferguson and the creation of the protest slogan "Hands up, don't shoot" typically chanted at protests against police violence.  Darren Wilson was later not indicted by a Grand Jury, leading to further protests.
Name: 2014: Michael Brown is fatally shot by white police officer Darren Wilson in Ferguson, Missouri.  The incident led to unrest in Ferguson and the creation of the protest slogan "Hands up, don't shoot" typically chanted at protests against police violence.  Darren Wilson was later not indicted by a Grand Jury, leading to further protests.

Text: Nine churchgoers were murdered during a Bible study at Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Charleston, South Carolina, by a white supremacist.  The murderer posted photos of himself posing with white supremacist iconography including the Confederate battle flag.  The shooting led to debates about memorialization of the Confederacy and display of the flag.  In the aftermath of the shooting, the South Carolina General Assembly voted to remove the Confederate battle flag from State Capitol grounds.
Name: 2015: Nine churchgoers were murdered during a Bible study at Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Charleston, South Carolina, by a white supremacist.  The murderer posted photos of himself posing with white supremacist iconography including the Confederate battle flag.  The shooting led to debates about memorialization of the Confederacy and display of the flag.  In the aftermath of the shooting, the South Carolina General Assembly voted to remove the Confederate battle flag from State Capitol grounds.

Text: Unite the Right Rally, a meeting of white supremacist, alt-right, Klansmen, and neo-Nazis, occurs in Charlottesville, Virginia.  This racist event turned violent when alt-right protesters clashed with counter-protesters, culminating in a white supremacist deliberately driving his car into a crowd of counter-protesters, killing Heather Heyer.
Name: 2017: Unite the Right Rally, a meeting of white supremacist, alt-right, Klansmen, and neo-Nazis, occurs in Charlottesville, Virginia.  This racist event turned violent when alt-right protesters clashed with counter-protesters, culminating in a white supremacist deliberately driving his car into a crowd of counter-protesters, killing Heather Heyer.

Text: George Floyd is killed while being arrested when a white Minneapolis police officer knelt on his neck for over eight minutes while three other officers looked on.  Floyd's death sparked thousands of protests against police violence across the United States and around the world, despite the COVID-19 pandemic.  Many protests were met with excessive force from the police.  The protests have led to the removal of Confederate monuments and calls for police reform.
Name: 2020: George Floyd is killed while being arrested when a white Minneapolis police officer knelt on his neck for over eight minutes while three other officers looked on.  Floyd's death sparked thousands of protests against police violence across the United States and around the world, despite the COVID-19 pandemic.  Many protests were met with excessive force from the police.  The protests have led to the removal of Confederate monuments and calls for police reform.

Text: Ahmaud Arbery is killed by three white men while jogging through a neighborhood in Brunswick, Georgia.  None of the suspects were arrested or charged until a video was released of the incident. The inaction by the police and the district attorney's office sparked debates about racial inequality in the United States.
Name: 2020: Ahmaud Arbery is killed by three white men while jogging through a neighborhood in Brunswick, Georgia.  None of the suspects were arrested or charged until a video was released of the incident. The inaction by the police and the district attorney's office sparked debates about racial inequality in the United States.

Text: The Durham County Confederate Soldiers Monument is dedicated.  Funded by taxes and organized by United Confederate Veterans and United Daughters of the Confederacy, the monument was erected in front of the County Courthouse.  The monument remained in that location until it was torn down in August 2017.
Name: 1924: The Durham County Confederate Soldiers Monument is dedicated.  Funded by taxes and organized by United Confederate Veterans and United Daughters of the Confederacy, the monument was erected in front of the County Courthouse.  The monument remained in that location until it was torn down in August 2017.

Images.alt_text: A black man seated behind a desk reads an issue of the Carolina Times.

Text: Louis Austin buys _Standard Advertiser_ newspaper, changes name to _Carolina Times_.  With the motto "The Truth Unbridled," Austin used the _Carolina Times_ reenergize black activism in Durham.
Name: 1927: Louis Austin buys Standard Advertiser newspaper, changes name to Carolina Times.  With the motto "The Truth Unbridled," Austin used the Carolina Times reenergize black activism in Durham.

Text: Thomas Hocutt, with the support of the NAACP, challenges white-only admissions at University of North Carolina pharmacy school.  Because James Shepard would not release Hocutt's transcripts, the case was dismissed for lack of standing.  However, it served as a test case to challenging the "separate but equal" doctrine in education and laid the groundwork for _Brown v. Board of Education_.
Name: 1933: Thomas Hocutt, with the support of the NAACP, challenges white-only admissions at University of North Carolina pharmacy school.  Because James Shepard would not release Hocutt's transcripts, the case was dismissed for lack of standing.  However, it served as a test case to challenging the "separate but equal" doctrine in education and laid the groundwork for Brown v. Board of Education.

External Resource Links.Resource Title: Durham Committee on the Affairs of Black People

Text: Durham Committee on Negro Affairs formed, beginning modern efforts for civil rights in Durham.  In its early years, the Committee focused on registering voters, running black candidates for local office for the first time in 1938, and getting blacks elected and appointed into position typically reserved for whites.
Name: 1935: Durham Committee on Negro Affairs formed, beginning modern efforts for civil rights in Durham.  In its early years, the Committee focused on registering voters, running black candidates for local office for the first time in 1938, and getting blacks elected and appointed into position typically reserved for whites.

Text: 68% of eligible black voters are registered in Durham County.
Name: 1939: 68% of eligible black voters are registered in Durham County.

External Resource Links.Resource Title: Southern Conference on Race Relations, Durham, N.C., October 20, 1942

Text: Black intellectuals meeting at North Carolina College draft Durham Manifesto for civil rights, leading to formation of Southern Regional Council in 1943.
Name: 1942: Black intellectuals meeting at North Carolina College draft Durham Manifesto for civil rights, leading to formation of Southern Regional Council in 1943.

Text: Confrontation between black GI stationed at Camp Butner and white ABC officer over liquor rations leads to race riot in the African-American neighborhood of Hayti.  A police officer and a white bus driver were injured.
Name: 1943: Confrontation between black GI stationed at Camp Butner and white ABC officer over liquor rations leads to race riot in the African-American neighborhood of Hayti.  A police officer and a white bus driver were injured.

External Resource Links.Resource Title: Miss Lyons Draws $5.00 Fine for Being Attacked

Text: Doris Lyons, 16, fined five dollars for refusing bus driver's order to "get in the back."  The arresting officer was absolved of the charge of assault and battery by the white judge proceeding over the case.
Name: 1943: Doris Lyons, 16, fined five dollars for refusing bus driver's order to "get in the back."  The arresting officer was absolved of the charge of assault and battery by the white judge proceeding over the case.

Text: Private Booker T. Spicely, a black GI stationed at Camp Butner is killed by white bus driver Herman Lee Council.  Council ordered Spicely to move to the back of the bus to make room for some white GIs getting on the bus.  When Spicely got off the bus after arguing with Council, Council followed him off the bus and shot him twice before continuing his route.  Council was acquitted of second degree murder by an all-white jury.
Name: 1944: Private Booker T. Spicely, a black GI stationed at Camp Butner is killed by white bus driver Herman Lee Council.  Council ordered Spicely to move to the back of the bus to make room for some white GIs getting on the bus.  When Spicely got off the bus after arguing with Council, Council followed him off the bus and shot him twice before continuing his route.  Council was acquitted of second degree murder by an all-white jury.

Text: Biracial ministers' committee formed to improve "racial cooperation."
Name: 1944: Biracial ministers' committee formed to improve "racial cooperation."

External Resource Links.Resource Title: JIM CROW LOSES; The Secret Game
A Courageous Act, Ahead of its Time

Text: A secret game of basketball is played between the Men's basketball team at the North Carolina College for Negroes (now North Carolina Central University) and the Duke University Medical School basketball team.  It was the first mixed-race sporting event in the modern South.  Due to the illegal nature of the game, the game was played on a Sunday morning when most of Durham, including the police would be in church and the participants were sworn to secrecy.  The North Carolina College team beat the Duke medical students 88-44.
Name: 1944: A secret game of basketball is played between the Men's basketball team at the North Carolina College for Negroes (now North Carolina Central University) and the Duke University Medical School basketball team.  It was the first mixed-race sporting event in the modern South.  Due to the illegal nature of the game, the game was played on a Sunday morning when most of Durham, including the police would be in church and the participants were sworn to secrecy.  The North Carolina College team beat the Duke medical students 88-44.

Images.alt_text: A black police officer is seated in the driver's seat of a police car.
Four black police officers stand together outside. Another officer stands off to the side.

Text: Clyde Cox and Allen Samuel become Durham's first black police officers to provide more police coverage for the Hayti community.  While part of the Durham Police Department, they were not allowed to use the bathroom or water fountains, eat lunch, or change their clothes at the police headquarters.
Name: 1944: Clyde Cox and Allen Samuel become Durham's first black police officers to provide more police coverage for the Hayti community.  While part of the Durham Police Department, they were not allowed to use the bathroom or water fountains, eat lunch, or change their clothes at the police headquarters.

Text: Durham Committee on Negro Affairs joins organized labor and white liberals in new political bloc formed by Democratic Party activist Les Atkins.
Name: 1946: Durham Committee on Negro Affairs joins organized labor and white liberals in new political bloc formed by Democratic Party activist Les Atkins.

Text: Motion picture _Negro Durham Marches On _produced.
Name: 1948: Motion picture Negro Durham Marches On produced.

Text: _Ebony_ magazine features Durham's Parrish Street as "Negro Wall Street of America."
Name: 1949: Ebony magazine features Durham's Parrish Street as "Negro Wall Street of America."

External Resource Links.Resource Title: Rencher Nicholas “R. N.” Harris, First African American on the City Council and the Durham County Board of Education

Images.alt_text: A group of white men hold their hands on a book and raise their other hands in the motion of taking an oath.

Text: Rencher N. Harris becomes first African-American elected to the Durham City Council.
Name: 1953: Rencher N. Harris becomes first African-American elected to the Durham City Council.

Images.alt_text: Dr. Martin Luther King stands behind a podium. Two other black men can be seen seated behind him.

Text: Martin Luther King, Jr., attends Durham Business and Professional Chain Trade Week, speaks at Hillside High School.  Invited by the Durham Business and Professional Chain as part of its Trade Week festivity, King told his audience, "Doors will be open to you now that were never open in the past. … Be ready for opportunities."  This was King's first visit to Durham.
Name: 1956: Martin Luther King, Jr., attends Durham Business and Professional Chain Trade Week, speaks at Hillside High School.  Invited by the Durham Business and Professional Chain as part of its Trade Week festivity, King told his audience, "Doors will be open to you now that were never open in the past. … Be ready for opportunities."  This was King's first visit to Durham.

External Resource Links.Source (Shortform): Durham Civil and Human Rights Map

Text: Durham Bulls have first black players, Bubba Morton and Ted Richardson.  Demonstrators attempt to integrate Durham Athletic Park seating on opening night by flooding the white-only entrance.  The demonstrators were denied entry through the entrance and were offered segregated seating and were eventually escorted off the premises.
Name: 1957: Durham Bulls have first black players, Bubba Morton and Ted Richardson.  Demonstrators attempt to integrate Durham Athletic Park seating on opening night by flooding the white-only entrance.  The demonstrators were denied entry through the entrance and were offered segregated seating and were eventually escorted off the premises.

Text: Durham Interdenominational Ministers Alliance passes a resolution for "a community free of discrimination and segregation"
Name: 1957: Durham Interdenominational Ministers Alliance passes a resolution for "a community free of discrimination and segregation"

Images.alt_text: Five black men and women kneel in prayer before a black minister.

Text: Sit-in occurs at Royal Ice Cream parlor.  Seven protesters, led by Reverend Douglas Moore entered Royal Ice Cream through the colored entrance, sat down in the white section, and asked to be served.  The group was refused and asked to leave.  When they refused to leave, they were arrested, charged with trespassing, and fined $10.
Headline: Royal Ice Cream Sit In
Name: 1957: Royal Ice Cream Sit In

Text: Black teachers admitted to summer institute at Duke University.
Name: 1957: Black teachers admitted to summer institute at Duke University.

Text: Parents of Joycelyn McKissick and Elaine Richardson sue for their daughters' reassignment to Durham High School.
Name: 1957: Parents of Joycelyn McKissick and Elaine Richardson sue for their daughters' reassignment to Durham High School.

Text: Mayor E. J. (Mutt) Evans forms Committee on Human Relations to address strained race relations.
Name: 1957: Mayor E. J. (Mutt) Evans forms Committee on Human Relations to address strained race relations.

Text: City tennis courts integrated.
Name: 1957: City tennis courts integrated.

Text: Rencher N. Harris becomes first black on Durham city Board of Education.
Name: 1958: Rencher N. Harris becomes first black on Durham city Board of Education.

External Resource Links.Resource Title: Hayti’s first fire company lacked resources, not courage

Text: Durham Fire Station No. 4 opens in Hayti.  It was the first Durham fire station to have an all African-American crew salaried by the city.
Name: 1958: Durham Fire Station No. 4 opens in Hayti.  It was the first Durham fire station to have an all African-American crew salaried by the city.

External Resource Links.Resource Title: Andree McKissick and Henry Vickers Integrate Carr Junior High

Images.alt_text: A black man, woman, boy, and girl walks on a sidewalk.

Text: City school board allows reassignment of eight black pupils to previously all-white schools.  Anita Brame and Lucy Jones are first to integrate, at Brogden Junior High.  Andree McKissick and Henry Vickers integrate Carr Junior High.  Joycelyn McKissick integrates Durham High School.
Headline: Durham schools integrate
Name: 1959: Durham schools integrate

External Resource Links.Resource Title: Lunch Counter Sit In at Woolworth Five & Dime
External Resource Links.Source (Shortform): Durham Civil and Human Rights Map

Text: Four days after the Greensboro sit-ins began, seventeen students from North Carolina College staged sit-ins at lunch counters at Woolworth, Kress, and Walgreen's.  They were accompanied by several white students from Duke University who pledged to occupy seats until the blacks were served.  The sit-ins led to the lunch counters being "closed temporarily in the interest of public safety.”
Name: 1960: Four days after the Greensboro sit-ins began, seventeen students from North Carolina College staged sit-ins at lunch counters at Woolworth, Kress, and Walgreen's.  They were accompanied by several white students from Duke University who pledged to occupy seats until the blacks were served.  The sit-ins led to the lunch counters being "closed temporarily in the interest of public safety.”

Images.alt_text: Dr. Martin Luther King with three other black men walk outside.
Dr. Martin Luther King preaching in a church. The organ and choir are visible behind him.

Text: A week after sit-ins began in Durham, Martin Luther King, Jr., and Ralph Abernathy visited Durham to speak to a standing-room only audience at White Rock Baptist Church.  Talking to the standing-room only crowd that filled the church, he counseled the crowd, “Let us not fear going to jail if the officials threaten to arrest us for standing up for our rights…Maybe it will take this willingness to stay in jail to arouse the dozing conscience of our nation.”
Headline: Martin Luther King Jr. visits Durham and speaks at White Rock Baptist Church
Name: 1960: Martin Luther King Jr. visits Durham and speaks at White Rock Baptist Church

Text: Duke University desegregates graduate and professional schools.
Name: 1961: Duke University desegregates graduate and professional schools.

Images.alt_text: Four black men inside a lobby facing a white man with his back to the camera. Other people are visible in the background.
A black woman stands at a ticket counter. A long line of black people is formed behind her.
Two black men, a white man, and a white police officer stand near each other.
A long line of black people formed along a sidewalk.
A long line of black people outside the Carolina Theatre.

Text: Protesters begin picketing Durham movie theaters including the Carolina Theatre.  When the management at the Carolina Theatre refused to desegregate, protesters began a rolling line protest that lasted for months.  When a protester approached the ticket window and was refused admittance to the white section of the theater, he or she went to the back of the line to try again.  Movie theaters desegregated in 1963.
Name: 1961: Protesters begin picketing Durham movie theaters including the Carolina Theatre.  When the management at the Carolina Theatre refused to desegregate, protesters began a rolling line protest that lasted for months.  When a protester approached the ticket window and was refused admittance to the white section of the theater, he or she went to the back of the line to try again.  Movie theaters desegregated in 1963.

External Resource Links.Resource Title: Civil Rights Demonstration at Howard Johnson’s Restaurant

Images.alt_text: A large group of people gather along the side of a highway outside a Howard Johnson's.
Three black men in suits standing outside. A fourth man is standing behind them with his back turned.

Text: Demonstrations begin at the Chapel Hill Boulevard Howard Johnson's Restaurant.  The goal of these protests was to integrate restaurants in Durham.
Attorney Floyd McKissick organizes Congress of Racial Equality chapter.
Name: 1962: Attorney Floyd McKissick organizes Congress of Racial Equality chapter.

Text: NAACP head Roy Wilkins and CORE head James Farmer visit, speak at St. Joseph's AME Church.
Name: 1962: NAACP head Roy Wilkins and CORE head James Farmer visit, speak at St. Joseph's AME Church.

External Resource Links.Resource Title: Lawyers Who Brought Suit to Integrate Durham Schools

Images.alt_text: Five black men stand and look at a piece of paper.

Text: Durham attorneys bring lawsuit against the Durham City Board of Education to integrate Durham public schools.  For the 1959-1960 school year, the African-American community submitted 225 reassignment requests but only 8 were approved.  Attorneys Conrad Pearson, Hugh Thompson, Floyd McKissick, William G. Marsh, and John H. Wheeler brought several cases against the Board of Education to completely integrate schools.
Name: 1960: Durham attorneys bring lawsuit against the Durham City Board of Education to integrate Durham public schools.  For the 1959-1960 school year, the African-American community submitted 225 reassignment requests but only 8 were approved.  Attorneys Conrad Pearson, Hugh Thompson, Floyd McKissick, William G. Marsh, and John H. Wheeler brought several cases against the Board of Education to completely integrate schools.

Text: Durham movie theaters agree to integration.
Name: 1963: Durham movie theaters agree to integration.

Text: Duke University desegregates undergraduate schools.
Name: 1963: Duke University desegregates undergraduate schools.

Images.alt_text: A large group of black people stand together, many with their arms in the air. One person holds a sign that says "You have the freedom to vote."

Text: 30-day mass-demonstration campaign for integrating of public facilities; 130 arrests on first night.
Name: 1963: 30-day mass-demonstration campaign for integrating of public facilities; 130 arrests on first night.

External Resource Links.Resource Title: R. Wensell “Wense” Grabarek, City Councilman and Mayor of Durham

Text: Mayor Wense Grabarek meets protest rally, forms Durham Interim Committee on race relations.
Name: 1963: Mayor Wense Grabarek meets protest rally, forms Durham Interim Committee on race relations.

Text: Most Durham hotels and restaurants integrate.
Name: 1963: Most Durham hotels and restaurants integrate.

Text: Public swimming pools and libraries integrate.
Name: 1963: Public swimming pools and libraries integrate.

Text: Industrial Education Center integrates programs in retail distribution and marketing.
Name: 1963: Industrial Education Center integrates programs in retail distribution and marketing.

Text: Chamber of Commerce and Jaycees open membership to blacks.
Name: 1963: Chamber of Commerce and Jaycees open membership to blacks.

Text: Federal court orders Durham city schools to adopt freedom-of-choice desegregation plan; pace of school integration accelerates.
Name: 1963: Federal court orders Durham city schools to adopt freedom-of-choice desegregation plan; pace of school integration accelerates.

Text: Black leaders petition Durham County schools to accept pupil reassignments.
Name: 1963: Black leaders petition Durham County schools to accept pupil reassignments.

Text: Durham County Citizens Council formed to oppose integration.
Name: 1963: Durham County Citizens Council formed to oppose integration.

Images.alt_text: Dr. Martin Luther King standing behind a podium.

Text: Martin Luther King visits Durham and speaks at the Jack Tar Hotel.
Name: 1964: Martin Luther King visits Durham and speaks at the Jack Tar Hotel.

Text: Durham Interim Committee replaced by Committee on Community Relations.
Name: 1964: Durham Interim Committee replaced by Committee on Community Relations.

Text: Durham County schools begin desegregation under freedom-of-choice plan.
Name: 1965: Durham County schools begin desegregation under freedom-of-choice plan.

Text: Activist Howard Fuller forms United Organizations for Community Improvement to encourage black political participation.
Name: 1966: Activist Howard Fuller forms United Organizations for Community Improvement to encourage black political participation.

Text: Demonstrations held for city schools to begin Headstart and Youth Corps.
Name: 1966: Demonstrations held for city schools to begin Headstart and Youth Corps.

Text: Asa Spaulding becomes first black on Durham Board of County Commissioners.
Name: 1967: Asa Spaulding becomes first black on Durham Board of County Commissioners.

Images.alt_text: A group of black people walking outside. Three armed, white men in uniforms stand and watch them.
A black man looks over his shoulder while standing with some other men. Other people can be seen in the background.

Text: Demonstrations over housing conditions turn violent; Grabarek summons National Guard to enforce order.
Name: 1967: Demonstrations over housing conditions turn violent; Grabarek summons National Guard to enforce order.

Text: Headstart and Youth Corps instituted in city schools.
Name: 1967: Headstart and Youth Corps instituted in city schools.
